title.narrative: Seminar on the 25th anniversary of ILO Convention No.169

description.narrative: The ILO Indigenous and Tribal Peoples Convention (No.169), adopted in 1989, is an unprecedented and visionary instrument seeking to ensure that indigenous peoples enjoy human rights without discrimination, exercise control over their own development and participate in decision-making processes that affect their lives. On the occasion of its 25th Anniversary, the ILO Office in Geneva, the Permanent Mission of Denmark the Permanent Mission of Mexico, the University of Lucerne and the International Work Group for Indigenous Affairs will organise an international seminar titled "Enabling rights-based development for Indigenous and tribal peoples - learning from 25 years' experience of ILO Convention No.169". The seminar will bring together more than 100 participants of ratifying and non-ratifying States. The concrete outputs of the seminar will be: - a short summary of discussions presenting key lessons drawn from 25 years' experience of the Convention No.169 - a knowledge-sharing publication on the contribution of Convention No.169 to rights-based and self-determined development for indigenous peoples (by IWGIA and the University of Lucerne).
